Burnout is recognized as a disease. Here are her symptoms
02 Nov 2019 by Victor Podvolotsky
Check yourself. Perhaps you need a sick leave.
The World Health Organization (WHO) first identified emotional burnout syndrome in the International Classification of Diseases, which is considered the standard for diagnosis and health insurance.
In the latest version of the catalog of the classification of diseases and injuries, WHO defines burnout as a result of chronic stress in the workplace that has not been successfully overcome.
There are three symptoms of emotional burnout:

feeling of exhaustion of energy and exhaustion;
increased mental detachment from work or a feeling of negativity and cynicism associated with work;
decrease in professional efficiency.

Burnout refers specifically to phenomena in a professional context and should not be used to describe experience in other areas of life, also noted in the classification.
An updated list of diseases and injuries, called ICD-11 (11 revisions), was compiled last year in accordance with the recommendations of healthcare experts around the world and was approved just the other day.
